abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Small and Medium Industries
            Project for Sri Lanka was comprised of two components,
            credit and technical assistance. The outcome of these
            components was mixed. They accomplished some of their goals
            but their impact was modest and sustainability is doubtful.
            While the Borrower performed satisfactorily, the Bank did
            not. These results stem from the overly ambitious goals of
            the project. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, only those institutions that are prepared to
            make a long term commitment to SMI (Small and Medium
            Industries) development through staffing and appropriate
            lending policy and procedures should be eligible to
            participate in future operations. Second, financial
            assistance alone cannot ensure successful implementation or
            operation of an SMI. Business advisory services are needed
            from project conception to commercial operation. Lastly, TA
            (Technical Assistance) programs under the project were
            rather ambitious and did not visualize the organizational
            and management weaknesses of the implementing agencies. Bank
            staff should have devoted more supervision effort in
            monitoring the implementation of these programs.
